choices.A: Add a custom domain name to the subscription.
choices.D: Instruct all the users to log off of their computer, and then to log in again.
choices.B: Deploy Windows 10 Enterprise by using Windows Autopilot.
choices.C: Create a provisioning package, and then deploy the package to all the computers.

questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) directory tenant named contoso.onmicrosoft.com.
All users have client computers that run Windows 10 Pro and are joined to Azure AD.
The company purchases a Microsoft 365 E3 subscription.
You need to upgrade all the computers to Windows 10 Enterprise. The solution must minimize administrative effort.
You assign licenses from the Microsoft 365 admin center.
What should you do next?

comments.content: Agreed! Answer is 'D'. Done this on 20 workstations.
Yes. Technically, the question doesn't mention the new E3 licenses being assigned. But D is definitely the quickest and most elegant solution.

discussion.content: Answer is wrong. There is no need to use autopilot for Pro -> Enterprise SKU update. With subscription based activation PRO -> Enterprise happens automatically when user has the license assigned and log in to device

Answer D is correct. This is the documentation:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-10-subscription-activation#how-it-works
"When a licensed user signs in to a device that meets requirements using their Azure AD credentials, the operating system steps up from Windows 10 Pro to Windows 10 Enterprise"
Devices are AAD joined. A license was assigned. The missing peace is only the sign in and out

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D

Selected Answer: D
Ill go with D

Selected Answer: D
D for sure.
D is the correct answer

Selected Answer: D

Selected Answer: D
D, please update the answers. I have paid for this exam.

The solution must minimize administrative effort.

D
In exam today and D is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: B
For sure B. While having the user log on and off may seem the easiest and simplest, it would not be. Even if this would be for 15 users, unless ~you~ are physically present and doing it, that would require overhead and is still not requiring the least amount of administrative overhead. I work for an MSP and getting just 5 users that we work with remotely for one of our companies to reboot is a PITA, and it's better for us to schedule a reboot instead, which is what AutoPilot can enable you to do in a sense. 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/autopilot/windows-autopilot#:~:text=Traditionally%2C%20IT%20pros,that%20is%20automated.

I love the D. This is literally one of the easiest ways to fix things when something is wrong. Rebooting the second easiest. But it makes sense because when licensing is changed, you have to sync the changes with a log on or go to Settings > Users > etc and sync.

I think D is not right as this needs on and off. Which means need administrative effort.
We need minimum administrative effort so I think D is not right option.
This is an MS-101 Exam Question I think
D for sure!

D is the correct answer. 
Microsoft 365 E3 include Windows 10 enterprise, but Office 365 E3 not. keep in mind this in de cuestion.

Ref : https://youtu.be/bk9wWc7x_m4

Take a look at this question https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/microsoft/view/2545-exam-ms-101-topic-1-question-33-discussion/ which is asked in last week MS-101 exam, the answer is subscription activation. 

The correct answer for this question is D.
D. The question specifies "minimize administrative effort."
D, no question about it.

D appears to be the correct answer:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-10-deployment-scenarios#windows-10-subscription-activation
It's D, absolutely.
D is correct to but it isn't mentioned in this course only Windows Autopilot is, so I would go for that if it comes up on the exam...

also done this in production recently - logging into device activates enterprise, I agree with Tommy

discussion.content: Got this question in the exam today
correct

- I just hovered over each option and this one made the most sense to me (but still unsure)

For second question, from hovering over 'use http-only cookie', this states it protects against cross scripting XXS. This one was obvious once I saw this.
Whatever man, do not understand these question nor answers nor explanations and dont care!

comments.content: I have generally found your comments very useful, Startkabels, thanks for that. But on this question you might as well not have commented. ;-)

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Translate URLs in Application Body to Yes.
If you set Translate URLs in application body to Yes, when your users access this application, the proxy will automatically scan for internal URLs that have been published through Application Proxy on your tenant.
Box 2: Use Http-Only Cookie to Yes.
The Use Http-Only Cookie setting allows Application Proxy to include the HTTPOnly flag in HTTP response headers. This flag provides additional security benefits, for example, it prevents client-side scripting (CSS) from copying or modifying the cookies.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/manage-apps/application-proxy-configure-hard-coded-link-translation https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/manage-apps/application-proxy-configure-cookie-settings

The first step is to download and install the Azure AzCopy tool, which is the tool that you run in Step 2 to upload PST files to Office 365. You also copy the SAS
URL for your organization. This URL is a combination of the network URL for the Azure Storage location in the Microsoft cloud for your organization and a Shared
Access Signature (SAS) key. This key provides you with the necessary permissions to upload PST files to your Azure Storage location.
Now you're ready to use the AzCopy.exe tool to upload PST files to Office 365. This tool uploads and stores them in an Azure Storage location in the Microsoft cloud.
After the PST files have been uploaded to the Azure Storage location for your Office 365 organization, the next step is to create a comma-separated value (CSV) file that specifies which user mailboxes the PST files will be imported to. You'll submit this CSV file when you create a PST Import job.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/securitycompliance/use-network-upload-to-import-pst-files

choices.C: Run azcopy.exe to copy the PST files to Microsoft Azure Storage
choices.E: Create a PST import mapping file.
choices.A: Create a Microsoft Azure Storage account.
choices.B: From the Microsoft 365 compliance center, retrieve the SAS key.
choices.D: From Exchange admin center, run a new migration batch.

discussion.content: In Exam today

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/use-network-upload-to-import-pst-files?view=o365-worldwide

Step 1: Copy the SAS URL and download AzCopy
The first step is to download the AzCopy tool, which is the tool that you run in Step 2 to upload PST files to Microsoft 365. You also copy the SAS URL for your organization. This URL is a combination of the network URL for the Azure Storage location in the Microsoft cloud for your organization and a Shared Access Signature (SAS) key. 

Step 2: Upload your PST files to Microsoft 365
Now you're ready to use the AzCopy tool to upload PST files to Microsoft 365

Step 4: Create the PST Import mapping file
After the PST files have been uploaded to the Azure Storage location for your organization, the next step is to create a comma-separated value (CSV) file that specifies which user mailboxes the PST files will be imported to. You'll submit this CSV file in the next step when you create a PST Import job.

Selected Answer: BCE
Ill go with the explanation.
Starting a migration batch i ruled out since its used to migrate mailboxes from Exchange onprem to online.
correct
BCE is correct

questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You plan to move several archived PST files to Microsoft Exchange Online mailboxes.
You need to create an import job for the PST files.
Which three actions should you perform before you create the import job? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

You have Windows 10 devices that are managed by using Microsoft Endpoint Manager. All the devices have Microsoft Office 365 apps installed.
You need to configure the proofing tool settings for the Office 365 apps.
From the Microsoft Endpoint Manager admin center, what should you create?

discussion.content: B for sure!
isnt this ms-101?

Selected Answer: B
Identified B with common sense;
Compliance policy is used to check if a device meets conditions but does not install or configure anything.
An app installs an application and M365 apps are already installed.
Device configuration policy in general configures devices and not apps.
Leaves B

comments.content:
I think Paolo is correct, because "You can create and use app configuration policies to provide configuration settings for both iOS/iPadOS or Android apps. "
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-configuration-policies-overview

Well, that's the theory. In practice, the answer is C, I tested that in my tenant.

Here is how you get there:
Microsoft Endpoint Manager admin center > Apps > All Apps > + Add > App type: Microsoft 365 Apps (Windows 10 and later) > Select > Next > Configure App Suite: Languages > Choose languages needed.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
tested:
A. device compliance policy -> NO, compliancy is not configuration
B. an app configuration policy -> NO, iOS/Android
C. an app -> NO, app already installed
D. a device configuration profile -> Yes this works

questions.question_text:
You publish an enterprise application named App1 that processes financial data.
You need to ensure that access to App1 is revoked for users who no longer require viewing the processed financial data.
What should you configure?

discussion.content:
Since no one like to provide proof, its C because "Access to groups and applications for employees and guests changes over time. To reduce the risk associated with stale access assignments, administrators can use Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) to create access reviews for group members or application access."


https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/governance/create-access-review#:~:text=Access%20to%20groups%20and%20applications%20for%20employees%20and%20guests%20changes%20over%20time.%20To%20reduce%20the%20risk%20associated%20with%20stale%20access%20assignments%2C%20administrators%20can%20use%20Azure%20Active%20Directory%20(Azure%20AD)%20to%20create%20access%20reviews%20for%20group%20members%20or%20application%20access.
C for sure!

Selected Answer: C
Makes sense, Access reviews have to option to automatically process recommendations and for example remove access for users that are not active. The Access review can be sent to reviewer(s) periodically and they can manually select users to remove,
Conditional access could be used, for example with a group condition but is very unpractical as the group still needs reviewing.
App protection does what the name suggests and is used to configure the context in which the app or its data can be used.
Owner I dont know
